awd_titl_txt: Service Facilities and Guideway Planning in Open Spaces Under Congestion and Disruption Risks
awd_abstract_narration:
Location of transportation service facilities (such as security gates at airports, transit stations near shopping malls) and layout of guideways (such as tunnels, gates and barriers) affect pedestrian traffic and poor design may induce congestion in both the immediate and surrounding contiguous spaces.  Failure to address congestion-related issues leads to deterioration in the efficiency of those facilities, and negatively impacts the general public, through unnecessary delay and safety hazards due to overcrowding. An extreme manifestation of poor design leading to congestion is devastating pedestrian stampede incidents in crowded spaces. The overcrowding situation is further worsened if some of the built facilities become unavailable for service from time to time. This research will create new methodology for planning efficient and reliable service facility location and guideway layout, while considering how pedestrian traffic will respond to the system design. It will provide key insights and strategies that will underpin improvement in design and ultimately result in significant economical and societal benefits for transportation, freight and manufacturing industries. This project will also lead to new educational practices by the creation and integration of education materials and a variety of outreach activities with transportation industries and public schools.
 
While it is well-known that many service systems are vulnerable to congestion and disruptions, studies on problems posed in open spaces are quite limited. This project will develop methodology to describe customer traffic fluxes, and overcome challenges associated with facility and guideway design using two complementing modeling schemes: one based on continuous/planar modeling techniques, and the other based on discrete model formulations to address a number of pressing challenges, including (i) point-wise service facility location design, (ii) integrated guideway deployment, and (iii) probabilistic service disruptions, in a variety of engineering contexts. The framework will enable quantification of the system performance either in analytical closed forms or in compact-sized (i.e., of low-order polynomial to the system size) expressions, either exactly or as high-fidelity approximations. This scheme opens up opportunities to transform a set of traditionally hard problems into solvable models.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
It is well-known that many transportation service facilities (such as security gates at airports, transit stations near shopping malls, tunnels, gates and barriers) are vulnerable to congestion and disruptions (e.g., due to blockage or shut-down), but studies on problems posed in open 2- or 3-dimension spaces are quite limited. This project investigated ways to plan transportation service facilities so that self-organized traffic can be better served despite both congestion hazards and random disruption risks. Novel mathematical model formulations are developed to describe customer traffic fluxes, and then used as building blocks to improve facility design via continuous/planar and discrete optimization models. A new set of solution methods are also created to address the highly complex models, using both analytical closed forms or compact-sized (i.e., of low-order polynomial) expressions.

A total of 21 journal papers, and over 40 conference presentations, are published based on research findings of this project. Two Ph.D. dissertations (Z. Wang and S. Xie) are based on research topics of this project, and they both received partial support from this project. A third current Ph.D. student (R. She) also contributed to more recent work in similar directions (with a particular focus on drone traffic modeling). The specific outcomes include the following.

First, this project has created a range of methodological methods to enhance efficiency and reliability of such systems, while fully taking into consideration how congested traffic will respond to the system design. Main findings cover the following areas: (i) how congested traffic flux shall cluster into service region partitions under Euclidean, rectilinear metrics, under continuous traffic equilibrium; Figure 1 below illustrates such a traffic pattern; (ii) how to design of traffic flow boundaries (e.g., traffic barriers, pavement guideways, drone dispatch sites) to control traffic and relieve congestion in a continuous space; (iii) how to manage shared mobility service in continuous spaces to enhance performance in equilibrium; (iv) how to build reliable systems that can address both congestion and random disruption risks, and/or place emergency responder facilities and resources to best respond to potential emergency incidents. 

Figure 1. How self-organized traffic travel in curves to avoid congestion. (left: one destination; right: multiple destinations) (Wang et al., 2022)

Second, this project has actively contributed to education, outreach, and practice. This project has led to new educational practices by creation and integration of education materials (new course modules) and a variety of outreach activities. We have worked with collaborators on field observation and experiments; for example, we worked closely with UIUC Facilities and Services to model pedestrian traffic on campus (particularly to assess the social distancing impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic) for our Illini Union, a few lecture halls, and the Krannert Art Center. This effort was recognized by the UIUC campus by listing the PI in the 'COVID-19 Wall of Recognition.'

Third, this project has allowed us to apply the methodologies and solution algorithms to a range of new emerging problems that have significant economical and societal importance. For example, in the last project year, we extended the traffic model and solution methods to address congestion of self-organized drone traffic in 2- or 3-dimensional aerial spaces, and to evaluate/optimize drone-based last-mile delivery services. Figure 2 below provides an illustration. Such new applications are growing rapidly in the freight transportation and manufacturing industries. Our publication(s) in this new direction has already attracted considerable attention from the community. 

Figure 2. Delivery drone traffic near a ground-based distribution center in various urban settings (She and Ouyang, 2021).
